ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I read a lot of biographies and learned what works and does not work for biography writing. Prof. Gaddis did a good job at choosing the biographies that we read in class. I also learned how to do research in the Beinecke and effectively write a story about someone's life.
Learning about the art of biography, which, to be sure is an art, and honing your writing skills sums up the task of the class.
The greatest skill I learned was how to weave a story together when you have a plethora of  original research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This course depended on seminar discussions, and most students did not participate in the classroom discussion. 
This course was well organized.

I learned a lot in this class, both during class discussion and outside-of-class original research. Students have to write a 25-page biography after discussing strengths and flaws of various biographies we read in class, which is rewarding and, for lack of a better term, cool. However, this class is a lot of work on a week-to-week basis, making it extremely hard to dedicate lots of time to the final project until near the end of the course.
It would be interesting to expand the readings to include more biographies of people who were not American.
Professor Gaddis is inspiring and engaging in terms of leading classes.
Mostly this class was perfect. The one thing I would like to see on the syllabus is a biography of an artist/writer other than Shakespeare.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely. It was the type of course I've always wanted to have as an undergraduate: very engaging and taught by a fantastic professor. Reading a full biography every week was quite a bit of work, but if you're able to give full effort it's also very rewarding.
This course is what you make of it. If you engage with the material and the assignments, you will learn a lot. If you don't, it will be a long slog of boring work.

Yes! Professor Gaddis has taught through many iterations of this course, so he knows which biographies to read and what questions to ask for effective discussion and learning. This course also provides an opportunity for doing original research at the Beinecke. It is a time consuming class, but one that is worth it for the class discussion and final project.

I strongly recommend this class. It is easily one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. It is challenging, but incredibly rewarding. If you do the readings, which is a book a week, and putting in the work going through the archives and writing the paper, which I spent about 100 hours doing,  you will have a new perspective on memory and how to properly retell a life. The variety of biographies in the class, ranging from novels to more traditional works, were revelatory and fun to read. The final paper takes time but the work feels urgent.
